PREFACE.

HAT kind of a reproof Uncle Toby will administer to the writer, when he shall discover that his quiet, un¬ obtrusive utterances in the sacred precincts of the family circle have been sent to the press without his authority, expressed or implied, I hardly know; although I am well aware that he is incapable of any thing very severe. In self-defense, I might appeal to his vanity, were it not that this quality has been wholly left out of his mental composition. Yet if I can be authorized by the favor of the public to an¬ nounce to him, erelong, that the work circu¬ lates well, and is doing good, he will readily

4

PREFACE.

forgive the rather violent shock to his modesty caused by its sudden appearance. I knew he would not consent to the publication, if asked beforehand ; and so it was a matter of neces¬ sity to postpone asking his permission until after the thing had been done irrevocably.

An announcement from the publishers greatly surprised me, however; namely, that I had copied so many of his utterances that not the half of them could be used, at present, without swelling the volume into too great a bulk. So it became quite necessary to eliminate a large number from the mass of materials furnished for the work.

It is earnestly hoped that the sentiments herein contained may be more acceptable to the generality of readers than a mere didactic treatise is likely to be. We more clearly discern and more readily apply what comes to us in a per¬ sonal form, so to speak, than what we meet in an abstract disquisition. The incidents of per¬ son, time, and place have a wonderful effect in vivifying the principles of moral conduct. And so much is this the case that I am inclined to

PREFACE.

5

think the personal narratives of our Lord by the four evangelists have clone vastly more than all the subsequent epistles to the Churches in mold¬ ing the characters of men. “ Heart speaks to heart” in this manner.

To grow old gracefully is a rare, yet alto¬ gether attainable, accomplishment. To do so requires an assiduous cultivation, through life, of the virtues of the heart, so that business shall not be allowed to incrust or petrify the sensibil¬ ities of the moral nature. One design of this work is to endeavor to depict a graceful, genial, lovable old age, in the person of Uncle Toby; and if this is in any wise fulfilled, the labor of preparing it will not have been bestowed in vain.

It is now committed to the favorable consid¬ eration of the public; and the blessing of God is implored upon it.

J. C. Wells.

Ottawa, III., May , 1875.

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

ABOUT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS.

ISGUSTING!” exclaimed my Uncle Toby, as he contemptuously flung upon the floor the morning paper which, according to his custom, he had been reading at the breakfast table. “ Disgust¬ ing!” he repeated. . *

“What is the matter, Uncle Toby?” cried out three or four of us at once, surprised by the sudden and violent sally of the venerable gen¬ tleman.

Before I tell you what his answer was, I must explain to you that Uncle Toby is quite an en¬ tertaining, every-day philosopher; and loves to descant upon men and things, at the close of the

9

I0 MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

meal, in an easy, dignified manner, meanwhile balancing his teaspoon upon the edge of the empty cup before him. In general, he is exceed- ingly good-natured, and delivers his utterances with the solemnity and majesty of an oracle ; as is his right by virtue of his earnestness and honesty. But sometimes, in his virtuous indignation against wrong-doing, he becomes quick, sharp, and petu¬ lant, as in the present instance.

He appeared somewhat startled by our explo¬ sive inquiry ; and then responded, “ I believe I ’m in favor of a monarchy here!”

“Well, I think that is indeed rather disgust¬ ing in a respectable, gray-haired, native-Ameri¬ can citizen, like yourself,” I ventured slily to re¬ mark.

Uncle Toby looked at me over .the top of his spectacles as gravely as an owl, and in as wither¬ ing a way as possible for him, until satisfied that he had restored me t© my usual becoming humil¬ ity ; and then condescended to reply, with a.quiet little smile.

“ I mean to say that our Presidential Elec¬ tions are disgraceful and abominable. If we were a nation of bedlamites turned loose, we could scarcely manage them worse than we do. Just look here,” and he held up side by side the Bing- town Gazette and the Bingtown Sentinel . “Ac-

ABOUT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS. II

cording to these two respectable authorities, if we elect one of the presidential candidates we shall have a ruler who is an accomplished liar, thief, traitor, and fool ; while if we choose the other, we shall have in the White House a tyrant, a gorilla, and a monster with two horrid heads and cloven feet! Now, is it not revolting in the extreme for honest, sensible people to be obliged to select between two such clusters of virtue as these?”

Here he stopped to recover his breath, which seemed well-nigh exhausted by the vehemence of his bitter ironical denunciation. Presently he re¬ sumed, more calmly:

“ In short, take these audacious newspapers for it, and the conferring and acceptance of a presidential nomination is in itself the ‘sum of all villainies.’ And look, too, at their sublimely im¬ pudent arrogance in claiming an infallible knowl¬ edge of the final result; all derived from actual canvass and count. Now, I said a little while ago, that, according to these authorities here,” and his lip curled scornfully, “we must take either one rascal or another to govern us. But it is much worse than that; for the said thorough canvass and careful count on both sides reveal the as¬ tounding fact, the National Constitution to the contrary notwithstanding, that we shall have them

12

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

both on our hands, the one by a majority on the popular vote, of at least 200,000; and the other of at least 250,000. And what is to be done in that event, I am sure I can not tell.”

We all joined in a hearty laugh here at the comical absurdity of the old gentleman’s per¬ plexity in view of the frightful catastrophe im¬ pending.

“ If,” he continued, “ there is no other way to suppress this outrageous indecency, the news¬ papers ought to be sternly prohibited by law to publish any thing but the current news, without comment. A public censorship would be infin¬ itely better than such a state of things as now exists.”

“Why,” I exclaimed, “would you abolish the liberty of the press ?”

“Liberty of the press?” he echoed; “do you call this the liberty of the press ? It is rather the licentiousness of the press. And, at the same time,, these papers are abject slaves to sel¬ fishness, party, and corruption. No ; I would break the fetters off them, and set them free. As it is, such newspapers are greater enemies of the public peace than the felon who steals our money. Shakespeare knew very well what he was saying when he wrote,

‘ Who steals my purse steals trash,’ etc.

ABOUT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS. 13

Now what would you think of a man who, in the name of liberty, should claim the right to indulge a course of actual lawlessness, by breaking win¬ dows, blocking the highways, knocking men down on the street, and such like. Would you throw around him the shield of our Constitution and laws? If the conduct of individuals is under constant surveillance, even in this Republic, why not the conduct of newspapers. Why should men as editors be allowed to run riot, any more than as private citizens ?”

“But, Uncle Toby, how will you undertake to remedy the matter?” I inquired.

“Ah, there you have me, my boy. How any practical measure can be brought to bear directly upon it, I do not know. The evil is too widely spread to be reached in the courts, even were the laws framed with that view. But they are not; and can not be, while the moral honesty of the people is held in abeyance by the politicians who seek to gain and hold office through the very clamor which constitutes the wrong to be sup¬ pressed. Besides, I say, if the laws could be passed, and if they might be executed, it is quite certain that they would not be actually carried into effect; but would become a dead letter on the statute-book, like the majority of prohib¬ itory liquor laws. And this is what made me

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

almost declare for a monarchy this morning,” and he uttered a sudden chuckling laugh. “But even if we had that, we would always be liable to have bad sovereigns, whom we could not remove. The only way I know, and it is the best way at any rate, is for the religious press to take the work in hand. I can well remember when it was almost as bitter and malicious as the political press is now. But it has become quite courteous in the discussion of differences, and so can very appropriately set itself, both directly and indi¬ rectly, to reform politics in this particular. And it needs not become partisan herein ; for the work is fully within its province, which is to oppose any thing and every thing corrupting and demor¬ alizing in community. Yet it has hitherto been silent concerning this matter, perhaps from a false modesty, and is therefore largely responsi¬ ble, in a negative way, for the prevalence of evil. If religious men were trained to frown down dishonest calumny, and demand mutual courtesy, the result could be accomplished. The political papers can not afford to disregard the wishes of Christian citizens ; for these are too numerous, and furnish too large a proportion of the support by which those papers are sustained. A failing subscription-list can be made a wonderful recti¬ fier of newspaper morals. But the teaching of

ABOUT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS.

15

the religious press ought to be constant, and not merely heard in the whirl of a campaign ; for then it may be overwhelmed. Settle the princi¬ ple beforehand, in the minds and hearts of the people; and they will be prepared for the issue when it comes.”

“I think you have made out a case, Uncle Toby,” said I.

“Yes, I think so too,” he replied, benig- nantly. “And suppose this plan were carried out, we would soon be done with mountebanks and buffoons trotting around over the country as political speakers, to excite the low passions of the multitudes. The orators would take their cue from the papers. They would speedily un¬ derstand that the better part of their hearers would not tolerate discourtesy and abuse, that their speeches would not be published ; or, if pub¬ lished, not read ; and they would adapt them¬ selves to the situation.”

“Just so,” I said.

“And,” he continued, “the very same moral sentiment of the people thus brought into active exercise, and applied to political affairs, would soon put an end to election frauds of all kinds, importing voters, substituting votes, fraudulent counting, and stuffing ballot-boxes. For infamy would follow detection; and detection would be

16

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

sure, in most cases, to result from the vigilance of honest men. So that the risk would be too great, and the penalty too severe to justify such experiments in behalf of ambitious politicians And the influence of all this would introduce and maintain purity in all departments of the Gov¬ ernment.”

“ Uncle Toby,” I interrupted, “you are quite an enthusiast. Do you think either you or I will ever see such a political millennium set in ?”

“As I said, it greatly depends on the religious press. Christianity is strong enough in this coun¬ try to effect the result, if Christians will only set themselves about it, which they will do, I believe, if the religious press keep their attention turned to its importance and obligation.

“And, besides, I was going to say, when elec¬ tions come to be fairly conducted, whoever is elected president will feel that he is not. the president of a party, but of the whole country, and that, in all his honest efforts to fulfill the duties of his high office, he will have the candid co-operation of all parties ; whereas, now, a pres¬ ident goes into office all bespattered with the cal¬ umnies of the campaign, to be malignantly watched and slandered throughout by the oppo¬ sition, and thus cruelly hampered by unjust sus¬ picions and downright misrepresentations. Of

ABOUT PRESIDENTIAL ELECTIONS.

17

course, there will be differences of opinion ; and honest criticism is, at all times, to be allowed, and fair courteous controversy encouraged. And thus, after full discussion, let the majority rule. And as we gain more light and wisdom, we can make such changes as may be desirable in our legislation.

“To be sure, also, if a rogue gets into office, or seeks to get into office, by cunning intrigues and hypocrisy, as must always be the case at times, he ought to be exposed and his dishon¬ esty be denounced. But even this should be, and would be if the press were pure, not hasty, rash, or eager; but with the calm and deliberate justice of an upright court, and only on evidence available and at hand. It would even be much better that occasionally a scamp should escape merited censure than that, as it is now, the honest and dishonest should alike, without dis¬ crimination, be condemned, merely for political effect. The offices could be surrounded by such guards and checks as, in connection with due care in selecting men to fill them, would, in the main, insure a proper discharge of duty therein. 0

Having thus fairly developed his philanthrophic scheme for the reformation of partisan politics. Uncle Toby settled down into a quiet se]f-satis-

2

18 MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

faction. And, his indignation having for the present subsided, he rose from the table, picked lip the offending papers, and, in his stately and deliberate manner, marched out of the room.

II.

CHURCH FAIRS AND FESTIVALS.

NE evening, just as we were finishing tea, Jennie Bryan came bouncing in, as she often did, being an esteemed friend of the family. However, at this time, there was a special item of business with my uncle, which she thus announced to him :

“Uncle Toby”—for so every body called him—“we are getting up a fair and festival for New-year’s, to buy some carpeting and furniture for our church ; and we want you to help us. The price of admission is twenty-five cents, and I have brought a ticket to sell you and, as she spoke, she produced the ticket, evidently expect¬ ing to close the transaction at once, knowing that he was always very liberal in contributing to a good work.

But she missed her aim, and received nothing but the word “Pshaw!” uttered so impatiently and harshly that tears started to her eves. And

19

20

MY UNCLE TOLY’S TABLE-TALKS.

my sister Lucy, with a* stare of astonishment, exclaimed :

“ Why, Uncle Toby !”

And well she might be astonished; for usually he is a remarkably polite and gallant old gentle¬ man, and none of us had ever known him to address a lady, or indeed any one, so rudely before.

Lucy’s exclamation decidedly woke him up; and he sprang to his feet, gently laid his hand on Jennie’s head, and said :

“Forgive me, my dear; I was absent-minded, and I am sorry I spoke so.”

Saying this, he gracefully impressed upon her forehead a kiss of reconciliation.

All of us, including Jennie herself, were heartily glad he had committed the blunder, since he atoned for it so grandly ; and we loved the dear old man more than ever, if that were possible.

“And now,” said he, resuming his seat, “I must give you a civil answer. I have no objec¬ tion whatever to contribute something to your carpet and furniture ; but I could not conscien¬ tiously buy a ticket to the festival, because I do not approve of such things.”

“Do you think them wrong, Uncle Toby?” asked Jennie.

CHURCH FAIRS AND FESTIVALS, 21

“ Wrong for me, my dear; but I do not set up my notions as a standard for any one. Many good people give their sanction to such methods of raising money; and probably they are as apt to be correct in their judgment as I am in mine.”

“Well,” said Jennie, “tell us what you have against them.”

And we all joined in the request.

“ As you seem to desire it, I will state my views ; but you need lay no particular stress on the old man’s notions of things. As I said ' be¬ fore, other people are as likely to be right as I am ; and they differ from me in opinion upon this matter*.”

So careful was he to avoid the appearance of condemning his brethren, even when he thought them in error.

“ I may say, then, in the first place, that, in connection with these fairs and festivals, I have observed methods adopted, sometimes, for ob¬ taining money, which look to me to border on gaming. For example, it is not uncommon to have what is called a grab-bag, filled with small articles drawn out, one at a time, by purchasers who pay for the privilege, and who must choose at random, not knowing what they may chance to get. And I have seen staid matrons, of the

22

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

highest standing for piety in the Church, super¬ intending this little catch-penny arrangement for promoting the interests of the Gospel; which, instead, appeared to my mind to stand at the very entrance of the way to the card-table. To be sure, gambling was not meant nor thought of, and the buyers respectively did not expect to obtain more than the value of the money paid— probably not so much as its value; but, still, there was the disposition brought into exercise of spending money on unknown chances, instead of open purchases; and so I always looked upon it, not only with a feeling of degradation, as though the dignity of religion were there being thrown away, but with the apprehension that the plan was directly fostering the gambling in¬ stincts of poor human nature, ‘always too prone to evil, even with all the dikes which can be thrown up to check and restrain the currents of depravity.

“ Again: I have witnessed another scheme, which I think tends to the same result, though not so objectionable, perhaps, as the one I have mentioned. I refer to what is called the post- office ; which, as a mere play for children, might be quite amusing and innocent, but, as a means of collecting money for religious uses, is more than questionable; not only giving rise to much

CHURCH FAIRS AND FESTIVALS.

23

nonsense, but encouraging the spending of money in the dark, and to no profit.

“The worst of all, in this point of view, is the ring-cake game, which contains the very essence of gambling, and differs nothing, in principle or morality, from any lottery or gift enterprise. A gold ring is baked in a cake, which is very thinly sliced ; and the slices are sold at about the price of the ring for each, the purchasers thus paying their money with the view of getting the ring in return with their cake. Comment on such a practice seems to me quite superfluous.”

“But, Uncle Toby,” said Jennie, “to quiet your apprehensions, I will inform you that we intend to have none of these things at our festi¬ val. I believe we are all opposed to them up our way as much as you are. We will only have square, open buying and selling ; and people can buy or not, just as they please—although,” she mischievously added, “ we may be tempted to put upon our articles a rather high retail price, the proceeds being devoted to a g ' ood cause.”

“ Well, my dear, I am glad to know that you intend to set none of those traps. It is a happy riddance, certainly. But, then, there are still other difficulties seriously in my way.”

“We would like to hear of them, Uncle Toby,” Jennie responded.

24

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

“Since I am at the confessional,” he replied, smiling, “ I will proceed, then, to unburden my mind, hoping at the end to receive absolution for any error. I have seen it arranged, at the close of festivals, to send to the poor—who, of course, were excluded from the scene of festivities by their want of money—the scraps and fragments which otherwise would have to go the dogs, and sell the valuable cakes at an auction, sometimes enlivened by witticisms, and even buffoonery, to make the articles go off briskly, just as we are likely to see in a street vendue. It always made me feel ugly, I regret to say, and brought forci¬ bly to mind certain Roman Catholic practices which you may find graphically described in Harper’s Monthly Magazine , for May, 1855, by a traveler in Brazil, South America. These occur some forty days after Lent, at a festival blasphe¬ mously called the Festival of the Holy Ghost ; which is preceded for about five weeks by solic¬ itors parading the streets, accompanied by negro musicians, carrying small crimson banners with the figure of a dove in a triangle, calling at every house, and gathering a grotesque collection of eggs, bread, fruit, dry goods, live fowls, etc., be¬ sides money. Connected with the festival itself are, of course, many blasphemous things which I shall not describe, leaving you to read the account

CHURCH FAIRS AND FESTIVALS.

25

for yourselves in “ Harper,” and with which I would by no means compare any thing in your decent festival. But as the auctions therein somewhat resemble ours, although much worse, I may be pardoned for referring to this point rather more clearly. Usually, a professional buf¬ foon is employed, whose business it is to sell cakes, pies, confectionery, live chickens, pigeons, etc. He frequently changes his costume, ap¬ pearing at one time as a general, then a bishop, then a Quaker, and so on. Occasionally, he takes his stand on a pair of stilts, and, to spy out a bidder, uses an enormous eye-glass ; that is ' a large tin ring. All sorts of antics are in¬ dulged to excite merriment and quicken bidding. Now, I have seen similar things, though not in so exaggerated a form, at our festivals and fairs. But even where antics are not practiced, nor drollery resorted to, in order to excite bidding, the very idea is revolting to me of procuring any adjunct of public worship, in any degree, by the results of an auction.”

“Well,” said Jennie, laughing, “I will see that there is no auction at our festival ; but the poor shall have the cakes, as well as the fragments. So you need not fear to come on that account.”

He resumed :

“You will say, perhaps, that hitherto I have

2 6

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

only spoken of abuses ; and that it is unfair to argue against the use of any thing ‘from its abuse. And, in principle, you will say rightly ; and yet the abuses I have mentioned are so apt to creep in that, to some extent, they have the force of legitimate argument against that to which they so readily attach. But let us look, now, at the essential features of the question. In gen¬ eral, it takes a month, or longer, to prepare for a fair and festival, or even for a festival alone. And the burden falls chiefly upon the ladies,—since the men • graciously ' leave the details to them, with a loving trust similar to that which leads the noble Indian husband to allow his squaw to hoe the corn, prepare buffalo-robes, pitch the wigwam, or take care of the ponies, while he goes fishing or hunting.”

We all laughed ; and Jennie remarked :

“You are too hard, Uncle Toby.”

“ Well, well, as I judge, I am only stating what I have observed. I do not mean to say that the men give no help at all ; but it is the women who are on the active committees, prin¬ cipally, and who, therefore, by the time the mat¬ ter is fairly over, are utterly disgusted, exhausted, and, perhaps, some of them laid on a bed of sickness, by their zeal and diligence in making the affair a creditable success. All in a good

CHURCH FAIRS AND FESTIVALS.

2 7

cause, of course ; but a good cause which could be better served in some other way, and in a nobler form of self-sacrifice, I think. They do not complain, it is true; and they would not thank me, I presume, for volunteering in their behalf; but I do wish men could be made to feel that the necessity—if it ever is really necessary— of this tiresome labor and anxiety—for there is always extreme anxiety for fear of failure on account of bad weather, indifference of the peo¬ ple, or some untoward accident—simply results from their delinquency in the duty of giving.

“ I know it is said that such things attract money from persons who are not members of the Church ; and, in a measure, it may be true. But I believe as much, or more, could be collected from the outside, without all this huckstering in the Church, by direct approach. For even sin¬ ners are not slow to recognize the wholesome influence of Churches in a community, and are therefore willing to contribute to their support. They who are otherwise are not seen at festivals. And those who are contributors are often absent likewise ; because, as is usually remarked, while it takes twenty-five cents to go in, it requires ten or fifteen dollars to get out again. They look upon it as a kind of trap, and so stand clear of it.

28

MY UNCLE TOBY’S TABLE-TALKS.

“And consider, also, that when a festival is not—as it frequently is—a downright failure, yielding not even expenses, the results are always meager in proportion to the exertions made and the time wasted in preparing for it. As an in¬ vestment, it surely does not pay. Money may be got together, it is true; but, ordinarily, a much greater sum can be collected in the same time, without the trouble and hard work it involves.

“ But I have not yet indicated my greatest objection to the whole matter. This is based on principle, and not policy ; and I will explain it as clearly as I can, so that you may understand me. I believe that the support and practice of relig¬ ion should be made a systematic business, as much as banking or selling dry. goods. And what would you think of a man who could only be induced to attend to his proper avocation by spasmodic enticements, and now and then giving him a party? You would surely regard him as very badly balanced, and hardly be inclined to humor his whim as to business, by thus leading him, as you would tole a pig along the high¬ way, by strewing grain where you wish to have it follow. And this explains what I meant a little while ago by saying that if there be any necessity for festivals, it is based directly upon

CHURCH FAIRS AND FESTIVALS.

“ Of course, the subject is too vast for me to offer a synopsis in the shortest form, even of a single branch of science ; but I desire to recall to your thoughts a few striking facts to show how we may trace the evidences of a designing hand and providence in every direction. Let us take a very familiar instance—the freezing of water. Now it is a law of nature that any sub¬ stance passing from a fluid to a solid state con¬ tracts in bulk, and becomes denser, and conse¬ quently heavier. Water follows this law down to forty degrees, eight degrees above the freezing point, where the law is completely reversed, so that, in the formation of ice, the fluid, though passing into a solid state expands, and becomes lighter, and remains at the surface for the pur¬ pose of protection. How disastrous it would be if the ice should, by increased density and weight, continually sink to the bottom, leaving the sur¬ face to freeze until the whole would be solidified in the rivers and seas, we can easily imagine.
